section: 8.1 TERM. The term of this Agreement shall continue for one (1) year following the Launch Date, unless earlier terminated as provided herein. This Agreement may be renewed for any number of successive one (1) year terms by mutual written agreement of the parties prior to the conclusion of the term of this Agreement. A party wishing to renew this Agreement shall give the other party notice thereof no less than thirty (30) days before the expiration of the term then in effect. A party wishing to renew this Agreement shall give the other party notice thereof no less than thirty (30) days before the expiration of the term then in effect. In the event that neither party expresses a desire to renew the agreement in writing, the term of this Agreement shall expire automatically.
explanation: The section repeats the sentence regarding the notice period for renewal. This repetition doesn't necessarily create a legal contradiction but introduces a structural flaw making the agreement less clear and potentially leading to confusion during interpretation. The repeated sentence doesn't add any new information and could be seen as redundant.

section: 9. INDEMNITY. Each party (the "Indemnifying Party") shall indemnify the other party (the "Indemnified Party") against any and all claims, losses, costs and expenses, including reasonable attorneys' fees, which the Indemnified Party may incur as a result of claims in any form by third parties arising from the Indemnifying Party's acts, omissions or misrepresentations to the extent that the Indemnified Party is deemed a principal of the Indemnifying Party.
explanation: This section creates ambiguity in text regarding the scope of the indemnification. The phrase "to the extent that the Indemnified Party is deemed a principal of the Indemnifying Party" significantly narrows the scope of the indemnification. It's unclear under what circumstances the Indemnified Party would be deemed a 'principal' of the Indemnifying Party. This introduces an ambiguity because the typical understanding of indemnity is broader, covering damages arising from the Indemnifying Party's actions regardless of a principal-agent relationship. This severely limits the protection offered by the indemnity clause.

section: 12.6 NOTICE. Any notices hereunder shall be given to the appropriate party at the address specified below or at such other address as the party shall specify in writing. Notice shall be deemed given: only upon personal delivery; if sent by fax, only if acknowledged by phone; or if sent by a reputable overnight courier with tracking capabilities, only three (3) days after the date of mailing:
explanation: The notice section has a structural flaw. It states that if the notice is sent via overnight courier, notice is deemed given three days *after* the date of mailing. This wording is awkward and potentially confusing. The standard expectation is that notice is effective upon receipt, not a fixed number of days after mailing, especially when overnight delivery is used. This creates ambiguity in the precise timing of when a notice is legally considered to be delivered.
